misconceptions.name: Implemented an entirely different problem (distance between points instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The submitted program solves a distance-between-points problem rather than the required grade calculator. It reads four doubles as coordinates, computes Euclidean distance, and prints that value, instead of reading a single numeric grade (0–100), using conditional ranges (A–F), and outputting a letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that writing a correct Java program (here, computing distance between two points) is sufficient for the assignment, or they confused this question with another task about distances.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must read one numeric grade from 0 to 100, use conditional logic (if/else-if/else) to check which range the grade falls into (A: 90–100, B: 80–89, C: 70–79, D: 60–69, F: below 60), and then print the corresponding letter grade in the specified format.
symptoms: Class name and output text refer to distance, not grades.
Program reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one numeric grade.
No conditional statements or Boolean expressions for grade ranges.
Output describes distance between points rather than a letter grade (A–F).
misconceptions.root_cause: Most likely confusion about the problem statement or mixing up files from a different assignment. The student did not translate the grade-mapping specification into an algorithm with input, conditionals, and corresponding letter output.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the grade calculator problem carefully. Start by changing the program so it asks for a single numeric grade (0–100) and stores it in a variable. Then write an if/else-if/else chain that checks the grade against the given ranges (>= 90, >= 80, etc.) and prints the correct letter grade. Remove all code related to coordinates and distance.
related_concepts: Relational and logical operators for range checks
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The class name, prompts, variables, and computation all clearly correspond to a distance-between-points task, and there is no trace of grade input, conditionals, or letter-grade output. This strongly indicates the wrong problem was implemented.

evidence.note: This main method reads four doubles as coordinates, computes Euclidean distance, and prints it, with no grade input, no conditionals, and no letter-grade output.

misconceptions.name: Submitted code for an entirely different problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that calculates the Euclidean distance between two points instead of the required Grade Calculator program (Q3). Consequently, the submission fails to address the input, logic, or output requirements specified in the rubric.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code intended for another assignment (Distance Between Points) instead of the Grade Calculator required for Q3.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The solution must specifically read one numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to map it to the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: The class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints'.
Input prompts ask for four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2).
The core logic calculates square roots and coordinate differences.
The output displays a distance value, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between assignment tasks or submission of the incorrect file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem statement for Q3 (Grade Calculator) and submit the correct code. Focus on using Scanner to read one grade and using if/else if statements to check the grade boundaries.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly calculates the distance between two points, as confirmed by the variable names, mathematical functions (Math.sqrt), and print statements, proving it is entirely unrelated to grade calculation.

evidence.note: The class name explicitly identifies the code as solving a different problem.
The input reads four coordinates instead of the single numeric grade required.

evidence.snippet: double distanceBetweenPoints = Math.sqrt(differenceX * differenceX + differenceY * differenceY);
evidence.note: The core calculation performs the distance formula, not grade range comparison.

misconceptions.name: Reads coordinate pairs instead of a single numeric grade
misconceptions.description: The program is structured to read two 2D points (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of reading a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 as required by the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that reusing a distance-between-points template that reads four doubles is acceptable for this assignment, or did not adapt the template to the grade-input requirement.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should prompt once for a numeric grade, e.g., "Enter grade:", and read a single number (int or double) representing the grade from 0 to 100.
symptoms: No variable representing a grade
Prompt text refers to coordinates instead of a grade
Program reads four doubles instead of one numeric grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reuse of an example program for computing distance between two points without adapting it to the grade-calculator specification, or misreading the task requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the coordinate prompts and four double inputs with a single prompt like "Enter grade: " and a single numeric variable (e.g., int grade = keyboard.nextInt();). Rename variables to reflect that they store a grade.
related_concepts: Translating problem descriptions into program structure
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompts and variable names clearly indicate a distance-between-points problem, not a grade input; there is no grade variable at all.

evidence.note: Instead of reading a single grade value, the program reads four doubles representing two coordinate points.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional logic for grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The program does not implement any conditional logic (if/else or similar) to check whether a numeric grade falls into the A or B ranges; in fact, it has no grade variable or Boolean expressions at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe that computing the distance between two points is the intended task or did not realize that they must check specific numeric ranges with conditionals.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The solution must use conditional statements (e.g., if/else-if/else) with Boolean expressions like grade >= 90 && grade <= 100 and grade >= 80 && grade <= 89 to classify the grade into letter categories.
symptoms: No if, else-if, or switch statements in the program
No Boolean expressions comparing a grade to 90, 80, etc.
All computation is numeric distance, not grade classification
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to implement the required decision-making structure, likely due to copying an unrelated example program or not focusing on the conditional-logic part of the specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an int or double variable grade, then write an if/else-if chain that checks grade against the specified ranges (90–100 for A, 80–89 for B, etc.) and prints the corresponding letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The body of main contains only arithmetic for distance and no conditional or Boolean logic at all.

evidence.note: All computation focuses on distance; there are no conditional checks or grade ranges anywhere in the program.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Outputs a numeric distance instead of a letter grade
misconceptions.description: The program prints a descriptive message with the numeric distance between two points, rather than printing a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on an input grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that producing the distance output message is appropriate for this question or reused code without adjusting the output to match the grade-calculator requirement.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should output a message like "Letter grade: B" based on the computed letter for the input numeric grade, not any distance or coordinate-related text.
symptoms: Output message refers to "distance of the two points"
Output is a double value (distance), not a letter character or string like 'A', 'B', etc.
No code constructs any letter-grade string
misconceptions.root_cause: Misalignment between the assignment's required output format and the student's implementation, likely due to copying or misunderstanding the target problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After determining the letter grade with conditionals, construct and print a message like System.out.println("Letter grade: " + letter); where letter is a char or String such as "A".
related_concepts: Mapping computed results to user-friendly messages
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only output line explicitly mentions distance and prints a double; there is no mention of grades or letters.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distanceBetweenPoints);
evidence.note: Instead of printing a letter grade, the program prints a distance description and a numeric value.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Program Implementation (Topic Implementation Mismatch)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points instead of the required Grade Calculator program. The entire functionality is incorrect for the assigned task.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for a completely different assignment or misunderstood the requirements entirely. The implementation focuses on inputting coordinates and calculating distance using the distance formula (Pythagorean theorem).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single integer/double representing a grade (0-100) and perform conditional logic (if/else if/else) to determine the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Code reads four inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one (grade)
Code calculates Euclidean distance instead of determining a letter grade
The class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints' not 'GradeCalculator' or similar
misconceptions.root_cause: Major misinterpretation of the assignment prompt or submission of incorrect code from a previous exercise.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem statement (Q3. Grade Calculator) carefully. Your submitted code calculates the distance between two points. You need to write a program that takes a numeric grade as input and uses if/else structures to output the corresponding letter grade based on the provided scale.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student code directly implements a different mathematical problem (distance formula) and contains none of the elements required for the assignment (grade calculation logic, comparison operators, or grade categories).

evidence.note: The entire program is dedicated to solving the distance between points problem, completely skipping the grade calculator requirement.

misconceptions.name: Wrong program submitted
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code for a distance calculator instead of a grade calculator. This indicates either a file mix-up or misunderstanding of the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code from a different assignment (distance between points) instead of the required grade calculator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires a single numeric grade input with conditional logic to determine letter grades (A-F). The code should use if-else statements to check grade ranges and output a single letter.
symptoms: Code reads four coordinate inputs instead of one grade
No conditional logic for grade ranges
Outputs a numeric distance instead of a letter grade
Class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints' not 'GradeCalculator'
No attempt to implement grade mapping or letter output
misconceptions.root_cause: File submission error or assignment confusion—student submitted code from a different problem entirely
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Compare the actual problem statement requirements carefully. Start fresh with the grade calculator: read one grade, use if-else to check ranges (90+, 80+, 70+, 60+, <60), and output the corresponding letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: 100% confidence—the submitted code solves an entirely different problem with no overlap with the grade calculator requirements.

evidence.note: Student reads multiple coordinate values instead of a single grade. Class name 'DistanceBetweenPoints' indicates wrong assignment.

evidence.snippet:
double distanceBetweenPoints = Math.sqrt(differenceX * differenceX + differenceY * differenceY);
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distanceBetweenPoints);
evidence.note: Code computes and outputs a distance metric. Should output a letter grade (A-F) instead.
Entire algorithm uses the distance formula. Grade calculator requires if-else conditionals for range checking, not mathematical calculations.
